Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the bottom left photo in the montage does not show the Dayton shooter, Connor Betts.
Understate: The claim understates the extent of the harassment faced by the misidentified Connor Betts, as it mentions that he faced harassment online but does not provide further details or examples.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that the misidentified Connor Betts faced harassment specifically because of his favorable opinions towards US President Donald Trump.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the misidentification of Connor Betts was the result of someone stealing his photo from his personal Twitter account and posting it online alongside photos of the Gilroy and El Paso shooters, without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not explore or provide alternative explanations for why the misidentified Connor Betts faced harassment online.
